author: By Ross Douthat
title: The Real White Fragility
description: Does the white upper class feel exhausted and oppressed by meritocracy?
content: In 2001, when I was still attending college, David Brooks wrote an essay for The Atlantic called “The Organization Kid,” in which he spent a lot of time with young Ivy Leaguers and came away struck by their basic existential contentment. Instead of campus rebels, they were résumé builders and accomplishment collectors and apple polishers, distinguished by their serenity, their faux-adult professionalism, their politesse.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Messman
title: What’s on TV Saturday: ‘Father Soldier Son’ and the Dance on Camera Festival
description: Stream a documentary about a family shaped by war, and catch a festival that celebrates all the ways dance can be represented onscreen.
content: FATHER SOLDIER SON Stream on Netflix. This documentary, which was directed by the New York Times journalists Catrin Einhorn and Leslye Davis, has been 10 years in the making. Though much has been reported about the hardships some soldiers and their families face upon returning home from combat, this film focuses on one family and chronicles its changing dynamic. It begins in 2010, when Master Sgt. Brian Eisch, a single father, leaves two young sons for a yearlong deployment in Afghanistan. He then returns home following a serious injury, which requires his leg to be amputated below the knee. His experience at war and back at home — where he not only struggles physically, but with a loss of identity — ultimately affects what his sons hope for their own futures. “Life, in ‘Father Soldier Son’ does not move in a circle," Jessica Kiang wrote in her review for The New York Times, “but in an incrementally decaying orbit around the values that, in making us what we are, also keep us from being anything else."
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Rogers
title: Trump Weighs In on the Death of John Lewis, One of His Most Vocal Critics
description: The president, who once described Mr. Lewis’s district as “crime infested,” expressed his condolences on Twitter a day after the congressman’s death.
content: WASHINGTON — The Republican governor of Georgia said that the country will “never be the same” without Representative John Lewis, who died Friday at age 80. The Democratic speaker of the house called Mr. Lewis “a titan of the civil rights movement.” The House minority leader said that Mr. Lewis “never stopped working to improve the lives of others.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zolan Kanno-Youngs
title: Were the Actions of Federal Agents in Portland Legal?
description: The Department of Homeland Security can point to federal statutes protecting property to justify the arrests of protesters in Portland, Ore., but whether they stretched the law would be up to a judge.
content: The Department of Homeland Security’s deployment of federal agents to Portland, Ore., has shown the broad legal authority an agency created to protect the United States from national security threats has to crack down on American citizens.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katharine Q. Seelye
title: John Lewis, Towering Figure of Civil Rights Era, Dies at 80
description: Images of his beating at Selma shocked the nation and led to swift passage of the 1965 Voting Rights Act. He was later called the conscience of the Congress.
content: Representative John Lewis, a son of sharecroppers and an apostle of nonviolence who was bloodied at Selma and across the Jim Crow South in the historic struggle for racial equality, and who then carried a mantle of moral authority into Congress, died on Friday. He was 80.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear
title: Inside the Failure: 5 Takeaways on Trump’s Effort to Shift Responsibility
description: President Trump and his top aides sharply shifted their pandemic strategy in mid-April after seizing on optimistic data suggesting the virus would disappear, a Times investigation found.
content: WASHINGTON — President Trump and his top aides decided to shift primary responsibility for the coronavirus response to the states during a critical period of weeks in mid-April, eagerly seizing on overly optimistic predictions that the pandemic was fading so the president could reopen the economy and focus on his re-election, a New York Times investigation found.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ronda Kaysen
title: Can I Stop Paying for Amenities That Closed Because of the Pandemic?
description: Gyms, playrooms and other commons spaces may be off limits, but that may not relieve your financial obligations.
content: Q: The gym, billiards room and children’s playroom in our apartment building have been closed for months, with no prospect of reopening anytime soon. We paid a premium for this apartment partly because of the amenity package. Now, we can’t use it. Should we get a credit for loss of services?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Courtney Rubin
title: The New Rules of Dating
description: Some people are single and ready to mingle (or … more than that), even amid a global pandemic. Here are some tips for doing so safely.
content: Dating is a complicated and often clumsy dance even in the best of times. Add in mask-wearing directives, social distancing and fear of a highly contagious virus for which there is no cure, and you get… well, an awful lot of people going out and doing some version of it anyway. A survey conducted by Everlywell — a company that makes at-home health tests — found that nearly one in four Americans ages 20 to 31 broke quarantine to have sexual contact with someone in April, when stay-at-home orders were at their peak.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jacey Fortin and Bryan Pietsch
title: Someone Tore Down a Union Army Statue in Saratoga Springs. Why?
description: The monument in a New York park was dedicated to men who volunteered to fight for the Union during the Civil War. It is unclear who toppled it, and for what reason.
content: Early on Thursday morning, the police in Saratoga Springs, N.Y., found a cast iron and zinc statue torn down from its stone pedestal in Congress Park and scattered in pieces on the grass.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kelly DiNardo
title: Breathe Better With These Nine Exercises
description: “You can’t be truly healthy unless you’re breathing correctly.”
content: Breathe. We do it roughly 25,000 times a day, but until recently few of us gave much thought to this automatic bodily function.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Genzlinger
title: Frans Nieuwendam, Who Knew Style and Had It, Dies at 60
description: He was a quiet force in fashion, though others knew him as the guy to try to impress on the rope line. He died of the novel coronavirus.
content: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Abrams
title: This Border Town Was on the Rise. Then the Pandemic Hit.
description: How the closure of the U.S.-Canada border in March devastated the economy of a Washington town.
content: BLAINE, Wash. — Over the past couple of years, Mike Hill poured more than $3.5 million into renovating his Chevron gas station and opening a Starbucks next door. People from British Columbia were crossing the border in droves to buy cheap gas and milk in Blaine, Wash. It seemed like a slam dunk investment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nathaniel Parish Flannery
title: Hardcore Cyclists Head for the Hills … Mexico City’s
description: With new bike routes and the pandemic pushing more people to cycle, the mountains outside one of the world’s megacities are drawing new and veteran enthusiasts.
content: Among Mexico City’s bicycling enthusiasts, the mountain road that twists up through the canyon in Los Dinamos National Park on the outer edge of the city, is a rite of passage.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Cheeky
description: John Guzzetta and Michael Hawkins present a puzzle with sass.
content: SATURDAY PUZZLE — I blame the dog days for dulling my senses, but this collaboration between John Guzzetta and Michael Hawkins (their seventh for The Times, by my count) required me to take a second, closer look to fully appreciate the nuances. It’s not extremely hard for a Saturday, and there’s a breezy quality about it that made my brain coast a little bit, but there’s a lot of riffing going on throughout that makes for a really cool and clever grid.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Apoorva Mandavilli
title: Older Children Spread the Coronavirus Just as Much as Adults, Large Study Finds
description: The study of nearly 65,000 people in South Korea suggests that school reopenings will trigger more outbreaks.
content: In the heated debate over reopening schools, one burning question has been whether and how efficiently children can spread the virus to others.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Editorial Board
title: Doing Schoolwork in the Parking Lot Is Not a Solution
description: In a pandemic-plagued country, high-speed internet connections are a civil rights issue.
content: When Autumn Lee, a pre-med junior at the University of New Mexico, needs to download lectures or class assignments, she hops in her car and drives 45 minutes to the McDonald’s nearest to her town of Sanders, Ariz., to connect to reliable Wi-Fi from her car. After the university sent students home because of the coronavirus pandemic, Ms. Lee grew frustrated with what she said is expensive and data-restricted internet service in Sanders, an unincorporated village of fewer than 1,000 people in eastern Arizona. Relying on her smartphone data plan wasn’t much of an alternative. “It took one or two hours to watch a 20-minute lecture,” she said. “I just got so frustrated, I figured there had to be another way.” So she made the 40-mile trek several times each week — and she’ll likely have to keep doing it now that the school has canceled nearly all in-person classes for the fall.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bernard Lafayette Jr
title: The First Time John Lewis and I Integrated the Buses
description: We just got on and sat in the front row. The bus driver insisted that we move to the back. But we didn’t move.
content: John Lewis, the civil rights icon, died on Friday. He had announced in December that he had Stage 4 pancreatic cancer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carol Rosenberg
title: For Families of 9/11 Victims, Virus Further Slows the Pace of Justice
description: With proceedings at Guantánamo Bay upended, chances are growing that the 20th anniversary will pass without the trial of the men accused of plotting the attack getting underway.
content: This article was produced in partnership with the Pulitzer Center on Crisis Reporting.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ivan Penn and Jim Wilson
title: How PG&E Is Racing to Improve Safety as Fire Season Approaches
description: The utility, which recently emerged from bankruptcy, is upgrading power lines, trimming trees and making other changes to prevent another big fire.
content: NAPA, Calif. — Atop an electrical pole overlooking grapevines, Pacific Gas & Electric recently installed a piece of equipment that will allow it to quickly turn off power to this part of California’s wine country when conditions for a wildfire are just right.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Phoebe Lett
title: Travel The World With Your Ears
description: Podcasts can drop you anywhere on the map, without having to leave the comfort of your own couch.
content: At this point in the summer — and the pandemic — the desire to escape to a place far away might be overwhelming. Even with so many borders closed, podcasts can transport you elsewhere, making them a good alternative to real, out-of-the-house travel. Here’s a collection of immersive audio experiences that are almost as immersive as exploring the great wide world out there.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: A More Liberal Supreme Court? Not When It Comes to Voting Rights
description: In four rulings in a row, the court has refused to ease voting restrictions.
content: For the fourth time since April, the Supreme Court this week made it harder for Americans to vote. The ruling, Justice Sonia Sotomayor wrote in dissent, was part of “a trend of condoning disfranchisement.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard A. Oppel Jr
title: Utility Company Gave Jobs to Allies of Top Illinois Democrat, Prosecutors Say
description: Illinois Speaker Michael J. Madigan has not been charged, but the governor, a fellow Democrat, said he must resign if the allegations are true.
content: When it came to a scheme to try to influence the speaker of the Illinois House, a politician so deft and powerful that he is known as the “Velvet Hammer,” a lobbyist had some plain advice for his client, Commonwealth Edison, the state’s largest electric utility, prosecutors say.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bret Stephens
title: American Crime and the Baltimore Model
description: Cities across the country are in danger of making the same mistakes.
content: In 2014, there were 211 homicides in the city of Baltimore. The following year, there were 342, an astonishing increase of 62 percent. The murder rate has barely budged since.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stacy Brick
title: Family-Friendly Movies Made by Diverse Filmmakers
description: These 8 movies were written, directed by and star people of color, and depict complex stories that can spark conversation.
content: For parents trying to figure out how to talk to their children about racism, film can be a useful tool for generating empathy. But many family-friendly movies with diverse casts are told from a white perspective, for a white audience. That can rob people of color of their turns as the hero, nullifying their voices. And the stories are usually about racism, presenting the issue as a problem to be solved, wrapping up in a neat resolution.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Haberman
title: Trump Promotes Caricature of What Conservatives Want
description: A series of events during his White House tenure has made clear that Mr. Trump views the voters he calls “my people” through the lens of what he imagines they like.
content: Standing in the White House colonnade this week, President Trump told an interviewer that he’s “comfortable” with “freedom of speech” extending to the Confederate flag.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rick Rojas
title: ‘They Didn’t Just Love Him. They Knew Him.’ Young Atlanta Activists Mourn John Lewis.
description: Mr. Lewis, who died on Friday, served as a connective tissue linking the lions of the civil rights movement to a new generation of activists in the city.
content: ATLANTA — By the time the Rev. James Woodall came to know John Lewis, Mr. Lewis was already a longtime congressman and a towering figure in the civil rights movement, one whose legacy loomed large over Atlanta.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kim Barker and Serge F. Kovaleski
title: Officer Who Pressed His Knee on George Floyd’s Neck Drew Scrutiny Long Before
description: In more than 19 years on the Minneapolis police force, Mr. Chauvin had a reputation as a rigid workaholic with few friends. He sometimes made other officers uncomfortable.
content: MINNEAPOLIS — The four teenagers drove around playing a game of Nerf Gun Assassin on a May evening before graduation in 2013. One of them randomly fired an orange dart out the window.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Nark and Akasha Rabut
title: California’s ‘Bear Whisperer’ Is Out of a Job
description: Steve Searles kept the bears in check in Mammoth Lakes, Calif., but quit his post after the coronavirus epidemic led to cuts in the town’s budget.
content: You can’t teach a misbehaving black bear a lesson through a Zoom conference call.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlie Savage and Adam Goldman
title: F.B.I. Agent in Russia Inquiry Saw Basis in Early 2017 to Doubt Dossier
description: Newly declassified documents added more fodder for the continuing political fight over an aspect of the Trump-Russia investigation.
content: WASHINGTON — A top F.B.I. agent recognized by February 2017 that a now notorious dossier of claims about purported Trump-Russia ties had credibility problems, but the Justice Department continued to rely on it as part of its basis to renew permission to wiretap a former Trump campaign adviser, documents released on Friday showed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Declan Walsh
title: As Seasonal Rains Fall, Dispute Over Nile Dam Rushes Toward a Reckoning
description: After a decade of construction, the hydroelectric dam in Ethiopia, Africa’s largest, is nearly complete. But there’s still no agreement with Egypt, which calls the structure a national security threat.
content: CAIRO — Every day now, seasonal rain pounds the lush highlands of northern Ethiopia, sending cascades of water into the Blue Nile, the twisting tributary of perhaps Africa’s most fabled river.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Doubles Play
description: We’re all made redundant in Wyna Liu’s Sunday debut.
content: SUNDAY PUZZLE — I often marvel at the number of clean theme entries a deft constructor comes up with for a Sunday grid (especially when I can’t come up with a single one, as often happens). When I figured out the trick today, I went in the opposite direction and briefly imagined how fun a giant mega-puzzle would be, with 26 examples, if that would even be possible. It’d certainly be over the top, maybe even in excess!
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Stevenson
title: China Is Dismantling the Empire of a Vanished Tycoon
description: Three years after Xiao Jianhua was snatched from a luxury hotel in Hong Kong, Beijing is making it clear that his style of freewheeling finance is a thing of the past.
content: HONG KONG — Xiao Jianhua was once a trusted financier to China’s ruling elite who came to represent an era of unbridled capitalism.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sergio Olmos, Mike Baker and Zolan Kanno-Youngs
title: Federal Officers Deployed in Portland Didn’t Have Proper Training, D.H.S. Memo Said
description: Rather than tamping down persistent protests in Portland, Ore., a militarized presence from federal officers seems to have re-energized them.
content: PORTLAND, Ore. — The federal agents facing a growing backlash for their militarized approach to weeks of unrest in Portland were not specifically trained in riot control or mass demonstrations, an internal Department of Homeland Security memo warned this week.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Remembering John Lewis, a Civil Rights Icon
description: Readers pay tribute to a man one calls “this nation’s conscience.”
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jan Hoffman
title: Mistrust of a Coronavirus Vaccine Could Imperil Widespread Immunity
description: Billions are being poured into developing a shot, but the rapid timetable and President Trump’s cheerleading are creating a whole new group of vaccine-hesitant patients.
content: Almost daily, President Trump and leaders worldwide say they are racing to develop a coronavirus vaccine, in perhaps the most urgent mission in the history of medical science. But the repeated assurances of near-miraculous speed are exacerbating a problem that has largely been overlooked and one that public health experts say must be addressed now: persuading people to actually get the shot.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: Republicans Keep Flunking Microbe Economics
description: Getting other people sick isn’t an “individual choice.”
content: Governor Ron DeSantis of Florida said something remarkably stupid the other day. I know, I know: it’s probably harder to find a day on which DeSantis didn’t say something stupid than a day on which he did. But this particular piece of thickheadedness, I’d argue, helps us understand why America’s response to the coronavirus has been so disastrous compared with other wealthy nations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ceylan Yeginsu
title: Long Waits for U.K. Hospital Treatment as N.H.S. Fights Coronavirus
description: With routine operations in England curtailed, some patients have experienced a significant deterioration.
content: LONDON — After nine months of waiting for surgery, Ruth Fawcett’s knee muscles wasted away, causing her joint to come loose in its socket and leaving her unable to walk without assistance.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Leland
title: Brigid Berlin, Socialite Who Joined Warhol’s World, Dies at 80
description: Born into privilege, she rejected her upbringing to become a fixture on the New York underground art scene of the 1960s and ’70s.
content: Here is one way to make a first impression.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rory Smith
title: Lost and Now Found, Leeds Returns to the Premier League
description: After 16 years away from English soccer’s top division, an era marred by sporting and financial batterings, Leeds United finally claimed a spot in the Premier League on Friday.
content: LEEDS, England — On the touchline, a member of the coaching staff had leapt into the arms of the defender Stuart Dallas, and was hanging onto him for dear life. Andrea Radrizzani, the team owner, was standing by the tunnel, embracing every player who approached him. In the stands, Victor Orta, the technical director, was pumping his arms and screaming into the sky.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alissa J. Rubin
title: ‘Our Role Is to Reduce Their Grief’
description: None of Iraq’s existing graveyards wanted the bodies of Covid-19 patients. So Shiite leaders created a burial ground for them that is also open to Sunnis and Christians.
content: THE DESERT WEST OF NAJAF — There are no signs to signal the way to the New Valley of Peace, or, as the Iraqis call it, the “Corona cemetery.” But it’s not hard to find: Just follow the cars. It’s the only place they are headed on the rough desert road.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Trump Administration Aims to Block New Funding for Coronavirus Testing and Tracing
description: The resistance to a funding proposal drafted by Senate Republicans has angered several members of the president’s party on Capitol Hill. The F.D.A. has issued emergency approval for pooled testing, a method that allows for much faster tracking of new infections.
content: The Trump administration has balked at providing billions of dollars to fund coronavirus testing and shore up federal health agencies as the virus surges across the country, complicating efforts to reach agreement on the next round of pandemic aid.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Derrick Bryson Taylor
title: Who Were the Freedom Riders?
description: Representative John Lewis was among the 13 original Freedom Riders, who encountered violence and resistance as they rode buses across the South, challenging the nation’s segregation laws.
content: Representative John Lewis, who died on Friday at 80, was an imposing figure in American politics and the civil rights movement. But his legacy of confronting racism directly, while never swaying from his commitment to nonviolence, started long before he became a national figure.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: To City’s Alarm, Federal Officers Police Portland
description: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, July 18, 2020.
content: “I feel like I’m being hunted for no reason.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tyler Kepner
title: Blue Jays Can’t Play Games in Canada Because of Pandemic
description: Canada’s immigration minister said repeated cross-border travel among players and staff members posed a health risk. The team is likely to play the regular season in the U.S.
content: Major League Baseball’s plan to use all 30 home ballparks for a shortened, 60-game season met an immovable obstacle on Saturday: the Canadian government. The Toronto Blue Jays, the only team in the league that is based outside the United States, will not be allowed to stage home games during the coronavirus pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anthony Tommasini
title: Gabriella Tucci, 90, Dies; Italian Soprano and Met Opera Mainstay
description: Ms. Tucci’s voice had luster, and she brought refinement to her singing. She sang 20 roles at the Met, where her heyday was the 1960s.
content: Gabriella Tucci, an Italian soprano whose richly expressive voice and beguiling stage presence made her a mainstay at major international houses — including, for 13 consecutive seasons, the Metropolitan Opera — died on July 9 in Rome. She was 90.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maureen Dowd
title: The Doctor Versus the Denier
description: Anthony Fauci’s at the pool, but Donald Trump’s in deep.
content: WASHINGTON — Never mind Johnny Depp and Amber Heard.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Editorial Board
title: John Lewis Risked His Life for Justice
description: His willingness to do so was essential to the quest for civil rights.
content: Representative John Lewis, who died Friday at age 80, will be remembered as a principal hero of the blood-drenched era not so long ago when Black people in the South were being shot, blown up or driven from their homes for seeking basic human rights. The moral authority Mr. Lewis exercised in the House of Representatives — while representing Georgia’s Fifth Congressional District for more than 30 years — found its headwaters in the aggressive yet self-sacrificial style of protests that he and his compatriots in the Student Nonviolent Coordinating Committee deployed in the early 1960s as part of the campaign that overthrew Southern apartheid.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabeth Egan
title: Learning to Heal, With a Little Fur Machine
description: In Joan Bauer’s “Raising Lumie,” training a future guide dog helps a newly orphaned girl navigate loss.
content: Everyone knows you’re not supposed to judge a book by its cover, but many of us do it anyway. In the case of Joan Bauer’s 14th novel, RAISING LUMIE (Viking, 288 pp., $16.99; ages 10 to 13), you might see the jacket photograph of a fuzzy yellow Labrador retriever puppy and assume you’re in for a cozy, heartwarming tale. You would be wrong. Sort of.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alix Strauss
title: Exploring Their Own Paths Together
description: Bonnie Brescia and Jeanette Poillon remain each other’s lifelines, even though both admit that they are polar opposites.
content: Because marriage is an ever-evolving experience, we constantly shift, change and, in some cases, start over. In It’s No Secret, couples share thoughts about commitment and tell us what they have learned, revealing their secret to making it work. (Answers are edited for context and space.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear, Noah Weiland, Eric Lipton, Maggie Haberman and David E. Sanger
title: Inside Trump’s Failure: The Rush to Abandon Leadership Role on the Virus
description: The roots of the nation’s current inability to control the pandemic can be traced to mid-April, when the White House embraced overly rosy projections to proclaim victory and move on.
content: WASHINGTON — Each morning at 8 as the coronavirus crisis was raging in April, Mark Meadows, the White House chief of staff, convened a small group of aides to steer the administration through what had become a public health, economic and political disaster.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Curtis Sittenfeld
title: Finally Write That Short Story
description: It’s time to stop talking about writing and write. The best-selling author of “Prep” and “Rodham” offers a plan.
content: Though some people have knocked out an entire short story in a single sitting, it’s more realistic to see writing a story not as an inspiration-fueled creative binge but as a multiweek project. It’s one you’re a lot likelier to finish if, rather than waiting for the muse, you create the possibility for inspiration by planning a time and setting up the circumstances that will allow you to write regularly. It also should be fun! The act of constructing plots, developing characters and creating dialogue can be challenging, even frustrating, but I never find it boring, and it just might allow you to escape from your daily life at the same time that you access the most imaginative parts of your own brain.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg and Mike Ives
title: Praise for John Lewis Pours in From Nation’s Political Elite
description: Mr. Lewis, who died on Friday at 80, was instrumental in the historic struggle for racial equality in the United States. “He risked his life and his blood” for his country, former President Barack Obama said.
content: WASHINGTON — A giant. A legendary leader. A civil rights icon. A human saint.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rebecca Martinson
title: Please Don’t Make Me Risk Getting Covid-19 to Teach Your Child
description: If I’m asked to return, I’ll have to walk away.
content: SEDRO-WOOLLEY, Wash. — Every day when I walk into work as a public-school teacher, I am prepared to take a bullet to save a child. In the age of school shootings, that’s what the job requires. But asking me to return to the classroom amid a pandemic and expose myself and my family to Covid-19 is like asking me to take that bullet home to my own family.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Broadwater and Kathleen Gray
title: Race Takes Center Stage as Rashida Tlaib Faces Primary Challenge
description: Some of Detroit’s most prominent Black leaders are backing a challenger to Ms. Tlaib, a Palestinian-American who has gained celebrity status since winning her seat in 2018.
content: HIGHLAND PARK, Mich. — Representative Rashida Tlaib, one of Congress’s most famous members, is perhaps best known for her membership in the progressive group known as “the squad” and her strident attacks on President Trump.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Morales
title: 2 Republican Senators Post Photos of Elijah Cummings in John Lewis Tributes
description: Marco Rubio and Dan Sullivan were each trying to honor Mr. Lewis on social media when they mistakenly posted photos of Mr. Cummings, a Black congressman who died in October.
content: Like thousands of other Americans, Senators Marco Rubio and Dan Sullivan took to social media on Saturday to mourn the death of Representative John Lewis, a venerated figure of the civil rights movement.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adriana Balsamo and Hilary Moss
title: Sing Figaro’s Aria and Diagram Your Garden
description: This week, watch Rossini’s ‘The Barber of Seville,’ learn the history of the ballot and chuckle at stand-up comics.
content: Here is a sampling of the week’s events and how to tune in (all times are Eastern). Note that events are subject to change after publication.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elian Peltier
title: Fire Hits Cathedral in French City of Nantes
description: The images of smoke pouring out of the Gothic building were a painful reminder of the fire that mauled Notre-Dame in Paris, but the authorities said the damage would not be as serious.
content: A fire broke out inside the cathedral of the western French city of Nantes in the early hours of Saturday, but the authorities quickly said there was no comparison with the blaze that engulfed Notre-Dame in Paris last year, despite ominous images of flames and smoke coming from the building.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bryan Pietsch
title: Oakland Will Pay $32.7 Million to Settle Ghost Ship Fire Lawsuits
description: The 2016 fire, which consumed a converted warehouse that had housed an artist colony, killed 36 people. It was the nation’s deadliest structure fire in more than a decade.
content: The city of Oakland, Calif., has agreed to pay nearly $33 million to settle lawsuits filed on behalf of the victims of a fire that killed 36 people in a two-story converted warehouse in 2016.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Higgins
title: Defying Kremlin, Protesters Stage Biggest Rally Yet in Russian Far East
description: Despite pleas and threats from Moscow, tens of thousands gathered peacefully in Khabarovsk and other cities to protest the arrest of a popular regional governor.
content: MOSCOW — Ignoring pleas from the Kremlin for calm after more than a week of unrest, protesters in the Russian Far East on Saturday staged their biggest display of defiance yet, with tens of thousands of people pouring into the streets to protest the arrest of a popular regional governor.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aimee Ortiz
title: How to Kill a Vampire: Not With This Kit, Apparently
description: The kit, complete with three crucifixes and a pistol, goes up for auction next week. Experts say it might not save you from the undead, but that’s beside the point.
content: Vampires, beware.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: July 18, 2020
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, July 18, 2020.
content: An article on Sunday about the relationship between China and Iran misstated the location of the academic institution where an Iranian energy researcher is based. The researcher, Ali Gholizadeh, is at the University of Science and Technology of China in Hefei, not in Beijing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margot Harrison
title: The Horror Novel Lurking in Your Busy Online Life
description: The genre relies on solitude and isolation to generate fear. But virtual connection is an illusion that cyber-horror writers are beginning to exploit.
content: In early April, at the height of the pandemic lockdown, Gianpiero Petriglieri, an Italian business professor, suggested on Twitter that being forced to conduct much of our lives online was making us sick. The constant video calls and Zoom meetings were draining us because they go against our brain’s need for boundaries: here versus not here. “It’s easier being in each other’s presence, or in each other’s absence,” he wrote, “than in the constant presence of each other’s absence.”
source.name: The New York Times

title: Creating a More Equitable Economy
description: Readers react to policy recommendations on the pay gap, inequality, education and more in a special Sunday Review issue called “The Economy We Need.”
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Frances Robles
title: Nicaragua’s Ruling Sandinistas Fall Victim to Covid-19, Highlighting the Disease’s Spread
description: The haphazard, politicized response to the pandemic by the country’s leaders has put the government’s own officials and supporters at particular risk.
content: A string of recent deaths across Nicaragua — including mayors, judges, police officials, sports figures, university rectors and government bureaucrats — is pointing to the chilling reality that the coronavirus is devastating this Central American country, although the government is not publicly acknowledging it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roni Caryn Rabin
title: A Covid-19 Lesson: Some Seriously Ill Patients Can Be Treated at Home
description: To ease pressure on hospitals, Northwell Health brought medical workers, oxygen tanks and intravenous equipment into patients’ homes. Now Florida is taking cues.
content: Joan Murray had been home with Covid-19 for about a week when she ran into trouble. She had a fever of 103 degrees and chills that sent shivers up and down her spine. Her oxygen levels were dropping, and the tightness in her chest felt “as if somebody had bound up my lungs with string.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elaina Plott
title: Why Trump’s Attacks on John Roberts Aren’t Working With Some Conservatives
description: The Supreme Court has faded somewhat in importance as frustration with the president grows, according to Republicans in the Indiana county where the chief justice grew up.
content: LA PORTE, Ind. — Mitch Feikes is one of many conservatives who disagreed with some of Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr.’s recent decisions, including striking down a restrictive Louisiana abortion law and ruling against the White House in its effort to undo an Obama-era immigration program.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Broadwater
title: Amid a Pandemic, Supporters Hope John Lewis Can Still Lie in State in the Capitol
description: More than 40 people have lain in state in the Capitol after their deaths. Some in Congress want the civil rights icon and 17-term congressman to receive the honor, even as the building remains closed to the public.
content: When Representative Elijah E. Cummings became the first Black lawmaker to lie in state in the Capitol last fall, the public poured into Statuary Hall, a choir from Morgan State University sang and admirers cried and hugged.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bill Pennington
title: Tiger Woods, Injured Grinder, Makes Cut at the Memorial
description: Woods slogged through back pain to birdie two of his final three holes on Friday, surviving the cut by one stroke.
content: DUBLIN, Ohio — When he was younger, Tiger Woods looked forward to getting older.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Firshein
title: What Is a Travel Columnist’s Role When Travel Stops?
description: Sarah Firshein, who writes a consumer advice column for The Times, found that her writing became more urgent after the coronavirus upended everything.
content: Times Insider explains who we are and what we do, and delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how our journalism comes together.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlie Warzel
title: 50 Nights of Unrest in Portland
description: Robert Evans of Bellingcat says the city “is being used as a bellwether to see what this administration can get away with.”
content: Thursday night marked the 50th consecutive night of demonstrations in Portland, Ore. The protests began after the killing of George Floyd — tens of thousands of people took to the streets to protest police violence and racial injustice. Since then, the protests have grown smaller, but clashes between law enforcement officers and protesters have escalated — on July 12, videos circulated of a federal officer shooting a protester in the head with a nonlethal munition, resulting in a skull fracture. Coverage of the unrest has caught the attention of President Trump, who vowed to “dominate” the protesters with federal law enforcement officers.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Crispiest Tofu Sandwich
description: Make Superiority Burger’s sandwich, or David Tanis’s black bean burger.
content: The week’s most popular dishes include Superiority Burger’s fried tofu sandwich (above), David Tanis’s black bean burger with a fried egg and Genevieve Ko’s crispy rice with shrimp, bacon and corn. Find more recipes in the collection below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elian Peltier
title: London Police Urged to Apologize After Officer Knelt on Man’s Neck
description: In a video, the detainee, who is Black, can be heard repeating, “Get off my neck,” as a white officer pins him. His lawyer said the encounter mirrored the treatment of George Floyd in the U.S.
content: LONDON — The lawyer for a Black man who repeatedly asked a white officer to “get off my neck” as he was pinned to the sidewalk during an arrest in London told a court on Saturday that the encounter echoed the treatment of George Floyd in the United States and called for a police apology.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jin Wu and Steven Lee Myers
title: Battle in the Himalayas
description: China and India are locked in a tense, deadly struggle for advantage on their disputed mountain border.
content: China and India are locked in a tense, deadly struggle for advantage on their disputed mountain border.
source.name: The New York Times

title: From the Archive: ‘Forgiving George Wallace’
description: John Lewis wrote in a 1998 Op-Ed about the best way to remember the former governor of Alabama.
content: John Lewis wrote in a 1998 Op-Ed about the best way to remember the former governor of Alabama.
